FacilityName: Buckeye Development and Logistics II - Huntington
ParentCompanyName: Buckeye Development and Logistics II - Huntington

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Although this is an existing facility (circa 1967), the Huntington Terminal endeavors to comply with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA #58) and API 2510 (at time of system construction) requirements for LP-Gas Storage with the objective of meeting the most current editions of each to the extent feasible and adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and Local codes/laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is the Facility's policy to contact the Huntington Fire Department and the Huntington County LEPC, as appropriate, through the 911 Service. The primary hospital response is provided through Parkview Huntington Hospital. The Facility is not currently designated a "responding" facility, however, the Facility currently maintains a trained incipient stage fire response and first responder-operations level hazardous materials response team to respond to the initial stages of an emergency.



Buckeye Development and Logistics, LLC - Huntington Terminal is a propane storage and distribution Terminal. The Risk Management Plan covers the propane storage and distribution process including three horizontal storage vessels, one underground cavern, propane loading stations, ethyl mercaptan odorant storage, and ancillary equipment. The three horizontal storage vessels will hold primarily a mixture of gasoline and propane (approximately 60% propane). This is used for the initial volume of pipeline receipts to prevent contamination and is reported conservatively as a Flammable mixture of 100% propane in this submittal.



Buckeye Development and Logistics, LLC - Huntington Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D- Program Level 3). Additionally, this plan meets the requirements of the U.S. Department of Labor- Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management regulations (inclusive of all 14 elements) for Highly Hazardous Chem

icals (29 CFR Part 1910.119).



This Facility has never had an accident or incident involving the propane storage and distrubution process resulting in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering-in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Huntington Terminal propane storage and distrubution process, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Huntington Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility's Facility Response Plan is coordinated with the Huntington Fire Department and the Huntington County LEPC. The Huntington Fire Department is aware of the Facility's propane storage and distrubution process, its safety systems, access points, and protective procedures in the event of a significant release.



Buckeye continually evaluates the process for opportunities to improve safety. Also, Buckeye makes every effort to coordinate annually at minimum with the local responders.
